text: The sea gives and the sea takes, but those who respect her waters will always find their way home.
A ship in harbor is safe, but that is not what ships are built for.
source: John A. Shedd, Salt from My Attic

text: The pessimist complains about the wind; the optimist expects it to change; the realist adjusts the sails.
Smooth seas do not make skillful sailors.
The only ship that sinks is the one that refuses to adapt to the changing tides.
Dead men tell no tales, but the sea remembers all.
Heed the warnings of the albatross; it flies between worlds and knows what we cannot see.
source: Samuel Taylor Coleridge, inspired by The Rime of the Ancient Mariner

text: The ocean is a mighty harmonist.
In a storm, pray to God but row for shore.
A sailor without a destination cannot hope for a favorable wind.
A bad day at sea is still better than a good day at the gallows.
The greatest treasures are those invisible to the eye but found by the heart.
source: Captain's Logbook of the Whydah Gally

text: Every sailor needs a star to guide by.
True navigation begins in the human heart.
The calmest seas hide the deadliest storms.
To sail is to be free, to captain is to bear the weight of that freedom.
